signs.sound-value: the glottal stop heard at the commencement of German words beginning with a vowel, ex. der Adler
signs.remarks: corresponds to Hebrew  ’āleph and to Arabic ’alif hamzatum.

signs.sound-value: usually consonantal y; at the beginning of words sometimes identical with ꜣ

signs.remarks: used under specific conditions in the last syllable of words, see §20.
used under specific conditions in the last syllable of words, see §20.

signs.sound-value: a gutteral sound unknown to English
signs.remarks: corresponds to Hebrew v ꜥayin, Arabic ꜥain.
corresponds to Hebrew nūn, but also to Hebrew lāmedh.
corresponds to Hebrew rēsh, more rarely to hebrew lāmedh.
corresponds to Hebrew hē, more rarely to Arabic hā.

signs.sound-value: perhaps like ch in German ich
signs.remarks: interchanging early with š, later with 𓐍 in certain words.
Originally two separate sounds: (1) z, much like our z; (2) ś, unvoiced s.
Originally two separate sounds: (1) z, much like our z; (2) ś, unvoiced s.
early hardly different from 𓄡 ẖ.

signs.sound-value: backward k; rather like our q in queen.
signs.remarks: corresponds to Hebrew qöph, Arabic ḳāf.
corresponds to Hebrew kaph, Arabic kāf.

signs.sound-value: the glottal stop heard at the commencement of German words beginning with a vowel, ex. der Adler

signs.remarks: during Middle Kingdom persists in some words, in others is replaced by t 𓏏.

signs.sound-value: originally dj and also a dull emphatic s (Hebrew lamed)
signs.remarks: during Middle Kingdom persists in some words, in others is replaced by d 𓂧.
